awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Response of Continental Hydrothermal Systems to Tectonic, Magmatic, and Climatic Forcing
awd_abstract_narration:
Continental hydrothermal systems have immense scientific and practical significance and are critically important to the Earth?s thermal budget and geochemical cycles. Continental hydrothermal systems are a primary source of economically important metal deposits, provide geothermal resources, support exotic ecosystems that are just beginning to be explored, and in some settings pose a significant  geologic hazard via hydrothermal explosions. The subsurface conditions and processes that control these systems are poorly understood because they entail the flow of multi-phase and multi-component fluids through rocks with heterogeneous permeability fields that are perturbed by a multitude of geological and environmental processes. Carefully designed multidisciplinary field experiments and modeling efforts are
required to understand the coupled processes that drive these dynamic systems and control their response to geological and environmental forcing.  This project is focused on quantifying the response of continental hydrothermal systems to tectonic, magmatic, and climatic processes operating on time-scales from seconds to thousands of years. The PIs address important and timely scientific questions, such as: How do multi-phase fluids and dissolved constituents flux through hydrothermal systems? How do these systems redistribute elements to produce mineral deposits and microbial habitats? How do earthquakes and magmatic activity perturb hydrothermal systems? What triggers hydrothermal explosions? How do environmental processes and climate affect continental hydrothermal systems?

The study will involve a combination of fieldwork, data analysis, and modeling. The field program uses a combination of innovative instrument networks and sediment coring activities that will be integrated through modeling activities to study the response of the Yellowstone Lake hydrothermal system to tectonic, magmatic, and climatic forcing. Yellowstone Lake is an ideal site for this research because it hosts an active hydrothermal system located in a region with high levels of tectonic and magmatic activity that has been influenced by a broad range of climate conditions in postglacial times. Research activities will include components of geochemistry, seismology, geology, geodesy, heat flow, micropaleontology, limnology, paleoclimatology, statistics, analytical modeling, and numerical modeling, all of which are essential for unraveling the coupled processes that drive system behavior. Working on a lake-floor system provides an exceptional opportunity to study forcing-response relationships on an expanded range of time-scales spanning more than 11 orders of magnitude.

por.por_cntn:
One of the largest and most energetic thermal basins in Yellowstone lies hidden beneath Yellowstone Lake. Its location beneath up to 120 m (~400 ft) of water has severely limited our ability to study the thermal features under Yellowstone Lake - in fact, most of these features were unknown until ~20 years ago. Understanding these features, however, is important because they are unusually sensitive to things like earthquakes and changing climate conditions, which can cause them to catastrophically explode.  The overarching goal of our project was to apply state-of-the-art marine and robotics technology to access and instrument the lake floor vent fields over a multi-year interval in order to understand how they respond to the various types of forcing they experience (e.g., annual lake-level fluctuations, wind-driven waves, earthquakes, caldera ground movements, etc.).

We conducted field work on Yellowstone Lake for three consecutive field seasons from 2016 to 2018. There were two components to our field strategy: geophysical and geochemical monitoring of the modern-day vent fields and sediment coring to study the postglacial (~15,000 year) history of hydrothermal activity beneath the lake. The sediment coring, conducted in 2016, collected eight cores with average lengths of ~10 m (~35 ft). The cores were split with one half being archived and one half being available for sample extraction. The cores were scanned and have been analyzed for their mineralogy and composition. The composition of the sediments provides information regarding the nature of extent of hydrothermal fluids that have interacted with them and how the lake and the surrounding watershed have responded to climate, hydrothermal, and geologic activity in the past. The sediment cores contain evidence for several previously unknown hydrothermal explosions in the lake, and provide new information regarding the potential triggering mechanisms.

The lake floor monitoring component, which ran from 2016 to 2018, included the deployment of a lake-wide network of pressure/temperature gauges, a variety of thermal instrumentation lake floor seismometers, magnetics surveys, and hydrothermal fluid monitoring equipment. Most of these activities were supported using the state-of-the-art miniaturized remotely operated vehicle (ROV) Yogi, designed and built by the Global Foundation for Ocean Exploration. ROV Yogi allows researchers working in Yellowstone Lake to have similar capabilities to those working with much larger ROVs at deep sea hydrothermal vents, including dextrous manipulation and sampling. In 2016 we also used a state-of-the-art autonomous robotic vehicle, REMUS, to generate a high-resolution map of the so-called ‘Deep Hole’ hydrothermal area. New instrumentation designed by team members at U. Minnesota allowed us to obtain ‘gas tight’ samples of hydrothermal fluid from the lake floor vents, which are critical for understanding the fluid chemistry. At 173°C (343°F), these are the hottest fluids ever sampled in Yellowstone, and they provide a unique window into the source of the hydrothermal fluids. Analysis of these samples allowed us to determine that ‘there is a steam wand under Yellowstone Lake’. In other words, the hydrothermal system under the lake is driven by steam, which is created when groundwater in the crust is heated by the magma bodies that underlie the caldera.

Results from the thermal instruments have shown that the Deep Hole thermal field is one of the largest on the Yellowstone Plateau, with a total heat output of ~28 MW. Combined with the fluid chemistry data, the thermal data also indicate that there is a steam reservoir underlying the lake at the Deep Hole field, with a lid at a depth of ~15 m below the lake floor. Magnetics data have shown that when condensed steam from this reservoir mixes with oxygenated lake water in pore spaces below the lake floor it demagnetizes the host rocks and creates a halo of low magnetism around the vapor up flow zone. This low magnetics signature remains even after fluid flow stops, such that the magnetics data provide a record of all the sites where hydrothermal discharge has occurred on the lake floor since the last glaciation (~15,000 years ago). The seismic data have shown that the lake radiates seismic energy into the surrounding region due to the interaction between wind waves traveling in opposite directions within the lake’s central basin. Thermal gradient measurements have shown that water column motions due to seiches (sloshing of the entire body of water within the lake’s basins) extend into the shallow sediments, which has implications for the mobilization of nutrients and solutes into the lake.

All of our field activities were documented via both photographs and videos, which were then used to create blogs and tutorials that were posted to the project website (hdylake.org). This material has been further collated, along with ‘artifacts’ from the field work and lake floor samples, to create an exhibit featuring our work at the Museum of the West in Cody, WY. This exhibit will be shown starting April, 2021.
